title: What is the safest way to practice popping casters?
content: Use a spotter, start with 2–4" pops on flat ground. Hands at ~11 o'clock, quick forward push with a lean back, then soft landing. Keep elbows soft, avoid yanking. Practice timing before attempting thresholds.

safety_notes: Use a spotter strap and check anti-tipper height.

title: How do I control speed down a ramp?
content: Lean back to keep weight over rear wheels, control speed by sliding handrims through hands at about 1 o'clock, and stay centered. Consider a spotter for steep descents.

safety_notes: Use gloves to prevent rim burn.
Avoid sudden full grabs on slick rims.

title: How do I avoid tipping backward while wheeling backward?
content: Lean slightly forward, use short even strokes, and stop by leaning forward and braking gently.

title: What are common errors when turning on the spot?
content: Over-gripping, letting hands leave the rims, and not counter-moving hands (one forward, one back). For tight turns, hold the inside wheel still and push the outside.

title: Which stroke patterns should I use for long distances?
content: Semi-circle or DLOP are best for steady or longer distances. Semi-circle provides periodic rest; DLOP uses a wrist flick and full release for speed and efficiency.

title: How do drag turns differ from push-off turns?
content: Drag turns: brush the wall behind your rear wheel, initiating turn after the axle clears the corner. Push-off turns: place hand ahead of rear wheel on wall and push away to turn. Manage pressure for sharpness.

title: How can I get up a curb solo?
content: Approach straight with momentum, pop casters 2–4" to land them on the curb, then lean forward and push rear wheels up. Spotter recommended for practice.

success_criteria: Rear wheels roll up without stall

title: How do I safely go down a curb backward?
content: Back up until rear wheels are at the curb edge, lean forward with chest toward thighs, pull back evenly on rims to control the drop. Keep casters up, then pivot them off one at a time; don’t sit up until casters land.

title: What’s the correct hand position when propelling?
content: Treat the wheel like a clock: hands engage between ~11 and 2 o'clock during push. This reduces shoulder strain and improves efficiency.

title: How do I stop quickly to avoid collisions?
content: Grab rims firmly at ~1 o'clock and lean back to increase braking, or if turning, lean into the turn and push the turn-side rim to divert.
